thread.title: Mayor's police body camera committee meets
thread.title_full: Mayor's police body camera committee meets | The Columbus Dispatch

author: The Columbus Dispatch
title: Mayor's police body camera committee meets
text:
Members of a mayoral committee charged with weighing the pros and cons of equipping 1,900 Columbus police officers with body cameras met for the first time today. 

After a study expected to take several months, the nine-person committee will recommend how the city will use the cameras, protect privacy, and pay for the technology. 

“There are three main hurdles that the committee needs to overcome,” Columbus Public Safety Director George Speaks said. “Our mission is to overcome these obstacles.” 

Today’s session included an overview of the technology and some scenarios meant to illustrate what officers encounter on the street. Future sessions should involve the review of best-practice policies, a public comment session, and guest speakers. 

Speaks said members of the committee, which met at the Columbus Police Division’s academy, come from across the community. 

The members include: Bo Chilton, who works for IMPACT Community Action; Kyle Erdeljac, with the Fraternal Order of Police; local business owner Gale Hill; Margot Kaminski, an Ohio State University law professor; Karla Rothan, with Stonewall Columbus; Abdikhayr Soofe, a member of the Community Relations Commission; Robert Stewart, assistant director with the Columbus Department of Public Safety; Columbus Police Cmdr. Robert Strausbaugh; and C. Dexter Wise III, a pastor with the Faith Ministries Church. 

Other Ohio police departments, such as Cleveland, Sunbury and the University of Cincinnati, already use body cameras. The state legislature is expected to vote on a bill in the coming months that would make body cameras mandatory for all police departments in Ohio. 

The cameras can be costly. Columbus’ own studies say it will cost $7 million to $10 million for the city to buy the cameras and to store and maintain the data captured by the cameras. The city also could pay a third-party vendor to store the footage. 

City Council President Andrew J. Ginther said last month that the committee likely would make its recommendations by the end of year, but Mayor Michael B. Coleman later said it will take the committee four to six months. 

Columbus Police Chief Kim Jacobs has said that body cameras are worth considering, but that her existing budget cannot support paying for them. She said there are other things her division needs, such as improvements to decaying substations and officer training.
